article_title: Vets looking forward to larger VA clinic in Conroe
article_text:
Vets looking forward to larger VA clinic in Conroe Cramped space will no longer plague doctors in growing area

Photo: Jerry Baker, Freelance ﻿The Conroe Veterans Affairs clinic, helmed by Dr. Jason Biscamp,... Folded blue wheelchairs and big cardboard boxes are stacked in the corner of Dr. Jason Biscamp's office at the Veterans Affairs clinic he runs in Conroe.

To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com. Houston Chronicle subscribers have FREE access to all premium digital products.

By logging in, you agree to the Terms and Conditions and Privacy Policy.

article_metadata.description: Folded blue wheelchairs and big cardboard boxes are stacked in the corner of Dr. Jason Biscamp's office at the Veterans Affairs clinic he runs in Conroe.  Another bathroom is filled with bags of dirty laundry and boxes of used syringes and other biohazard materials.  In the coming months, the VA will move its Conroe outpatient clinic from its current cramped quarters - where medical exam tables double as desks - into a new building that's three times as large.  Conroe's clinic opened in 2007 after Brady, Tellier's group and local veterans lobbied for more health care services for veterans in the outlying Houston areas.  Biscamp expects the demand to increase even more because of the number of returning Iraq and Afghanistan veterans, more health care enrollees under the Affordable Care Act, and the growth of the region.  A room where medical staffers monitor veterans who need urgent care also holds a cabinet where the clinic stores its medicine and, like most of 21 medical exam rooms at the clinic, it simultaneously serves as a nurse's office.  R.L. Mann, a Navy veteran of the Vietnam War who lives in New Caney, was being treated for post-traumatic stress disorder at the Conroe clinic Thursday.
article_metadata.author.name: By Mihir Zaveri
